pageData.text: An investigation of the inheritance of two characteristics, stem color and leaf plant height, will be conducted in this lab exercise using Wisconsin Fast Plants<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>. The inheritance of traits will be studied in three generations and the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotypes</button> will be recorded during the seedling stage. The seeds of one parent population and seeds for the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generations will be provided, so that predictions can be formulated. After the seeds germinate, the results will be analyzed, and predictions will be compared. The activities can be completed in eight days at the specified conditions.

Infer genetic traits from observed phenotypes.
Propose and test models for inheritance of the phenotypes for the plant specimens provided.
Compare the predicted results with the data collected.

pageData.text: Mendelian genetics is based on seven pea plant traits that Gregor Mendel studied for decades. Mendel discovered that these traits are either or . One of the traits that Mendel observed was pea seed color - green (recessive) or yellow (dominant). In 2007, researchers identified the pea color gene, sgr, that Mendel was ultimately tracking. When seeds are yellow, the sgr gene turns on, synthesizing a protein that breaks down the green pigment, chlorophyll. Green seeds have a non-functional sgr gene, thus the chlorophyll remains in the seed, which appears green.

Skin color in humans is not inherited as simply as seed color in Mendel’s pea plants. Skin color is a polygenic characteristic, meaning it is affected by many different genes. Children will not always have the same skin tone as their parents. Other polygenic traits include hair color and height. In fact, most traits are affected by a combination of multiple genes and the environment. Mendel was fortunate that he studied non-polygenic traits: if they were polygenic, he may have never started to unlock the secrets of inheritance.

pageData.desc: Five members of a family that each have a different skin tone.
pageData.altText: Five members of a family that each have a different skin tone.

pageData.text: The modern understanding of genetic inheritance is based, in part, on the research of Gregor Mendel (1822–1884), an Austrian monk who performed carefully controlled studies of trait inheritance in pea plants. As Mendel worked with peas, he discovered patterns in the physical traits in different generations of offspring. An example is seed color (yellow or green) or seed texture (wrinkled or smooth). These traits were passed from generation to generation in predictable patterns. Based on his findings, Mendel developed two important laws: the <button class='glossary-text'>law of segregation</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>law of independent assortment</button>.

Mendel’s first law, the law of segregation, states that individuals possess two <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> for each trait. When organisms are crossed, the offspring randomly receive one allele from each parent for a particular trait. Alleles are different forms of the same gene that code for slightly different expression patterns of a genetic trait. The two alleles may or may not be identical. When two different alleles are present, the trait that is expressed is <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button>; the allele that is not expressed is <button class='glossary-text'>recessive</button>. In one of Mendel’s experiments, the tall parent plant was <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous dominant</button>, meaning that both of its alleles were for the “tall” trait. The short parent plant was <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous recessive</button> because it possessed two matching “short” alleles. All the offspring in the first generation were <button class='glossary-text'>heterozygous</button> and had one “tall” allele and one “short” allele (e.g., tall/short). The heterozygous <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button> resulted in expression of the dominant trait, which was the tall <button class='glossary-text'>phenotype</button>.

At the time Mendel was working, there were multiple hypotheses for the mechanism of inheritance. However, terms such as phenotype, the physical expression of a trait, and , the genetic traits, which combine to create an individual’s genotype, did not exist. The use of these terms throughout this manual is a result of the “Modern Evolutionary Synthesis,” which combined the 19th century work of Charles Darwin and Gregor Mendel with 20th century theories of the molecular mechanisms of inheritance.

Mendel’s second law, the law of independent assortment, says that all traits are inherited independently of one another. This means that wrinkled seeds will not always be yellow, and smooth seeds will not always be green. Instead, seeds can be yellow and wrinkled, green and wrinkled, yellow and smooth, or green and smooth. Mendel’s laws help explain heredity (which traits are passed from one generation to the next) and variation (the differences between parents and their offspring).

The genetic information for a specific trait is usually written with the same letter of the alphabet representing both <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button>. An uppercase (capital) letter represents the <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> allele, and a lowercase letter denotes the <button class='glossary-text'>recessive</button> allele. The two alleles written together represent the <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button> of an organism. For example, the genotype of a tall, <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous-dominant</button> parent can be written as TT, whereas the genotype of a short, <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous-recessive</button> parent can be written tt. The genotype of the first generation of offspring includes one allele from each parent and is denoted as Tt. The outward expression of genotype is the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotype</button>. This is what we see when we examine an organism. For example, the tall, first-generation pea plants in Mendel’s experiment exhibited the tall phenotype and the Tt genotype.

The first two organisms that are crossed are called the Parental generation (). All descendants of the P generation are part of the Filial generation (). Offspring of the P generation are F1. The F1 offspring can be bred to each other, which in turn produce F2, which then produce F3, etc. When only one set of traits is being tracked in a cross, it is a monohybrid cross (i.e., if we are only interested in flower color). A cross that involves two sets of alleles is a dihybrid cross (i.e., tracking flower color and seed texture); see Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.

pageData.question: If one parent is homozygous dominant for a gene and the other is homozygous recessive for the same gene, what is the probability that one of their offspring will be heterozygotic?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 100% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will be heterozygotic.

pageData.question: If one parent is homozygous dominant for a gene and the other is homozygous recessive for the same gene, what is the probability that one of their offspring will be homozygous?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 0% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will be homozygotic.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The first two organisms that are crossed are called the parental generation (P generation). All descendants of the P generation are part of the filial generation (F generation). Offspring of the P generation are F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>. The F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> offspring can be bred to each other, which in turn produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>, which then produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>, etc. When only one set of traits is being tracked in a cross, it is a monohybrid cross (i.e., if we are only interested in flower color). A cross that involves two sets of alleles is a dihybrid cross (i.e., tracking flower color and seed texture).  Punnett squares can also be used to calculate the probability of an offspring having a given genotype, or to calculate the expected distribution of genotypes in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generations.

img.alt: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The first two organisms that are crossed are called the parental generation (P generation). All descendants of the P generation are part of the filial generation (F generation). Offspring of the P generation are F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>. The F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> offspring can be bred to each other, which in turn produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>, which then produce F<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>, etc. When only one set of traits is being tracked in a cross, it is a monohybrid cross (i.e., if we are only interested in flower color). A cross that involves two sets of alleles is a dihybrid cross (i.e., tracking flower color and seed texture).  Punnett squares can also be used to calculate the probability of an offspring having a given genotype, or to calculate the expected distribution of genotypes in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generations.

img.alt: Figure 1: dihybrid cross with potential F2 generation phenotypes when parents are heterozygous.

pageData.text: A table called a <button class='glossary-text'>Punnett square</button> can be used to show the results of genetic crosses. This useful tool was named for Reginald Punnett (1875–1967), a Cambridge biologist who verified and expanded on Mendel’s work. To draw a Punnett square, write one set of parental <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> across the top of the grid, and write the other set of alleles vertically down the left-hand side of the grid. For a monohybrid cross, each parental allele is listed separately in a column or row. Each box in the Punnett square represents a specific combination of parental alleles and is determined by column and row placement. Fill in each box by writing the allele for the column and the allele for the row side-by-side. Refer to Figure 2, which shows how to draw a Punnett square for a monohybrid cross.

Before conducting studies on inheritance, biologists typically establish true-breeding (homozygous) stocks for the traits they are interested in studying. For most controlled genetic studies, the individuals in the <button class='glossary-text'>P generation</button> will be homozygous for the traits in question. In this lab, you will only be growing seeds from Parent 1 of the P generation.  These seeds are labeled P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> for Parent 1.  You will use Punnett squares to predict the genotype and phenotype of the other parent, Parent 2 (P<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>) as well as the offspring.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Figure describing the steps of building a Punnett square
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Figure describing the steps of building a Punnett square

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Punnett squares</button> can also be used to calculate the probability of an offspring having a given <button class='glossary-text'>genotype</button>, or to calculate the expected distribution of genotypes in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generations. For instance, in the cross demonstrated in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button>, one parent is homozygous <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> for the gene in question (AA) and the other is <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous recessive</button> for the same gene (aa). Completing the cross in the Punnett square shows that all possible combinations of <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> will result in a <button class='glossary-text'>heterozygous</button> individual. There is a 100% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will have the genotype Aa. Said another way, we would expect 100% of the offspring to have the genotype of Aa. If the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation are crossed back to each other the cross would be expressed as seen in Figure 3. To calculate the probability that an individual offspring will have a particular genotype, add the number of times that genotype appears in the table and divide by the total number of possibilities (Table 1). In this case, Aa appears twice; so, two divided by four is 0.5, giving us a 1/2 (1:2) probability that any given offspring will be Aa. We would also expect that 50% of the offspring in that generation will have that genotype. Similarly, AA and aa only appear once. One divided by four is 0.25, so 25% of the offspring will have either of those genotypes; see Table 1. Since the combination of genes during mating is a mostly random occurrence, actual percentages may vary in real populations, but the larger the population is, the closer to these ratios the data will be.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Punnett square showing the result of an F1 cross
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Punnett square showing the result of an F1 cross

pageData.text: Probabilities for multiple genes can be calculated by multiplying the probabilities of each together. If pea plants homozygous for the tall gene (TT) and homozygous for the yellow pea gene (YY) were crossed with plants for both traits (TtYy) (Figure 4), the crosses would each result in 50% homozygous and 50% heterozygotes (Table 2). To determine the expected percentage of TTYY individuals in the F1 generation, the odds of TT (0.5) are multiplied by the odds of YY (0.5), yielding a probability of 0.25 or 25% ().

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Punnett squares showing results for the height gene and the seed color gene
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Punnett squares showing results for the height gene and the seed color gene

pageData.question: If one parent has the genotype TtYy and the other is homozygous dominant for the same genes, what is the probability that one of their offspring will be heterozygotic for both traits?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 25% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will have the genotype TtYy.

pageData.question: If one parent has the genotype TTYy and the other has the genotype Ttyy, what is the probability that one of their offspring will have the genotype ttyy?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There is a 0% probability that any individual in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation will be homozygous recessive for both genes.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Probabilities for multiple genes can be calculated by multiplying the probabilities of each genotype together. Let’s use two pea plants as an example: one pea plant homozygous for both the tall gene (TT) and the yellow pea gene (YY) is crossed with a plant heterozygous for both traits (TtYy). Taking each gene into account separately, any offspring has a 50% chance of being either homozygous dominant or heterozygous for each gene. To determine the expected percentage of TTYY individuals in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation, the odds of TT (0.5) are multiplied by the odds of YY (0.5) yielding a probability of 0.25 or 25%.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Probabilities for multiple genes can be calculated by multiplying the probabilities of each genotype together. Let’s use two pea plants as an example: one pea plant homozygous for both the tall gene (TT) and the yellow pea gene (YY) is crossed with a plant heterozygous for both traits (TtYy). Taking each gene into account separately, any offspring has a 50% chance of being either homozygous dominant or heterozygous for each gene. To determine the expected percentage of TTYY individuals in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation, the odds of TT (0.5) are multiplied by the odds of YY (0.5) yielding a probability of 0.25 or 25%.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Start by setting up a fluorescent light source. In Activity 1, you will create watering systems for P1 and F1 seeds, then place these seeds in their respective systems. After waiting 3 days, observe the P1 and F1 seedling phenotypes and determine the phenotype percentages. You will then predict the F2 generation phenotypes and proportions. Next, you will create a watering system for F2 seeds and place the seeds in the system. After waiting 3 days, observe the F2 seedling phenotypes and determine the phenotype percentages.

In Activity 1, you will create watering systems for P1 and F1 seeds, then place these seeds in their respective systems. After waiting 3 days, observe the P1 and F1 seedling phenotypes and determine the phenotype percentages. You will then predict the F2 generation phenotypes and proportions. Next, you will create a watering system for F2 seeds and place the seeds in the system. After waiting 3 days, observe the F2 seedling phenotypes and determine the phenotype percentages.

content.text: Note: Fast Plants® seeds are genetically engineered to grow extremely fast and are very sensitive to heat. If a common incandescent light source is used, the heat from the light will “cook” the seeds, and they will not grow. A cool light source needs to be used for this experiment. A fluorescent light or LED is needed to provide a cool, white light source. Inexpensive fluorescent light bulbs are now readily available and will fit into a traditional desk lamp.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: A replacement investigational kit for Mendelian Genetics (item number 580108_Bio) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely. Remember to observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What is the probability of an offspring with the genotype RRGg from the following cross?RrGG x Rrgg
If two heterozygous individuals produce four children, what is the probability that all the offspring will be heterozygous?

In a plant species, purple flower color (P) is dominant to white flower color (p), and flowering in the spring (F) is dominant to flowering in the summer (f). Which of the following describes the phenotype of a plant with the genotype PpFf?

options.text: a plant with purple flowers that blooms in the spring
a plant with purple flowers that blooms in the summer
a plant with white flowers that blooms in the spring
a plant with white flowers that blooms in the summer
a plant with pale purple flowers that blooms between spring and summer

assestmentData.question: In humans, a single gene codes for the red blood cell antigens that define the ABO blood groups. The gene can code for an A-antigen, a B-antigen, or no antigen at all. Which of the following best describes these three versions of the antigen gene?
A dihybrid cross will produce all possible combinations of genotypes and phenotypes in the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generation if the traits crossed abide by which of the following?
Which of the following is NOT a needed-but-not-supplied item for this investigation?
In a monohybrid cross tracking an eye color gene (B, b), which of the following best describes the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation offspring?
Which of the following is a safety hazard associated with this investigation?

options.text: There are no special safety concerns for this investigation.
The Fast Plant<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> seeds are a choking hazard.
The investigation uses glass which may break.
Hydrochloric acid is a corrosive material.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

Prepare a fluorescent light area. This area should contain a fluorescent light that can be raised and lowered, so that it maintains a height of 5–10 cm above the Fast Plants<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>.

Fast Plants<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> seeds are very small. Forceps may be helpful for positioning the seeds in the petri dishes. If your envelope does not contain the stated number of seeds, do not worry. The percentage of seeds will be used for all of the calculations.

In Activity 1, you will germinate three generations of Wisconsin Fast Plant<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> seeds over the course of 8 days. On Day 1, you will plant the P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> seeds and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation seeds. On Day 4, you will record the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotypes</button> of Parent 1 (P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>) and the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> generation plants and make predictions about the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generation plants. On Day 5, you will plant the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generation seeds. On Day 8, you will record the phenotypes of the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generation and compare your predictions to the observed ratios.

pages.title: Examination of the Intact Brain (4 steps)

typeBefore.text: In this activity, plants from one of the true-breeding parent populations and from the first generation of offspring will be grown up. Based on the results, predictions will be made about the <button class='glossary-text'>genotypes</button> for these populations, and the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotype</button> and genotype of both the other parent population and the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> generation.

typeBefore.title: Planting P1 Seeds and F1 Generation Seeds

pageData.text: Cut a sheet of filter paper into 4 strips of approximately 1 cm × 8 cm each. Set the remaining filter paper aside.
Place approximately 3 cm of the end of a filter paper strip into the inverted lid (larger half) of a petri dish.
Use a pipet to place 2-3 drops of water on the end of the filter paper strip in the petri dish. This will help to hold the filter paper in the dish.
Use a pencil to label one of the whole pieces of filter paper “P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>”.
Place the labeled piece of filter paper in the petri dish that contains the filter paper strip.
Pour water into the petri dish, and saturate the filter paper thoroughly.
Pour off the excess water.
Evenly space 10 of the P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> seeds around the labeled filter paper.
Place the bottom (smaller half) of the petri dish above the inverted lid to form a dome. The filter paper strip should extend out from the closed petri dish.
In a new petri dish, repeat Steps 2–9 with the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> seeds, but label the filter paper “F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>”.
Carefully place both dishes under a fluorescent light source. (The light should be 5–10 cm above the petri dish.)
Place another petri dish under the lamp, and fill the bottom (smaller half) with water.
Place the protruding ends of the P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> filter paper strips into the dish of water. See Figure 5.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Petri dish and filter paper set-up. One dish is filled with water. The other contains the filter paper. A small strip of filter paper bridges the gap between the dishes, wicking water from one dish to the dish with the filter paper. Both dishes are covered by lids
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Petri dish and filter paper set-up. One dish is filled with water. The other contains the filter paper. A small strip of filter paper bridges the gap between the dishes, wicking water from one dish to the dish with the filter paper. Both dishes are covered by lids

pageData.text: Note: The filter paper strip will act as a wick to keep the Fast Plant® seed moist. Therefore, place as much of the filter paper strip as possible into the water dish. Minimize the amount of filter paper exposed to the air; the goal is to prevent the paper from drying out.
Place the lid (larger half) on the water dish. Check this dish daily to make sure it does not dry out during the course of the experiment.

typeBefore.text: On Day 4, examine the seedlings for the purple stem trait and the dwarf stem height trait. Purple pigment in any part of the leaves or stem indicates that the purple stem trait is present. Stems that are shorter than a plant with a normal stem height are said to have the dwarf stem height trait (See Figure 6 for comparison).

typeBefore.desc: Figure 6: Fast Plant leaf phenotypes; one is dark green while the other is a pale yellow green
typeBefore.altText: Figure 6: Fast Plant leaf phenotypes; one is dark green while the other is a pale yellow green

pageData.text:
Count the number of plants that have:
  • A purple stem and a dwarf stem height
  • A purple stem and a normal stem height
  • A non-purple stem (green stem) and a dwarf stem height
  • A non-purple stem (green stem) and a normal stem height
Record the results in Data Table 1.
Determine the percentage of each generation that has each phenotype.
Record these percentages in Data Table 1.

typeAfter.text: The F1 plants had two parents: P1 and P2. Based on your observations of Parent 1 (P1) and the F1 generation plants, what would you expect Parent 2 (P2) to look like had you grown it? Record this in Data Table 2.

pageData.text: Rinse the petri dishes with water, and dry them with paper towels.
Fill the bottom of a petri dish with water. This will be the water reservoir for all 5 petri dishes in this investigation.
Cut 5 strips of filter paper to approximately 1 cm × 8 cm each. Set the remaining filter paper aside.
Place approximately 3 cm of the end of a filter paper strip into the inverted lid (larger half) of one petri dish.
Use a pencil to label an uncut piece of filter paper “F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>”.
Place the labeled piece of filter paper in the petri dish that contains the filter paper strip.
Pour water into the petri dish and saturate the filter paper thoroughly.
Pour off the excess water.
Evenly space 10 of the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> seeds around the labeled filter paper.
Place the bottom half of the petri dish on top of the inverted lid to form a dome. The filter paper strip should extend out from the closed petri dish.
Place one end of the filter paper strip (from Step 3) into the reservoir petri dish and the other end into the petri dish that contains the seeds.
Repeat Steps 3–10 to set up 4 more identical plates, each with 10 seeds. Each petri dish that contains seeds will be connected to the water reservoir with a filter paper strip.
Place the lid on the water reservoir petri dish. Check this dish daily to ensure that the water does not dry out.
Carefully place the fluorescent light source above all 6 petri dishes.
Note: Make sure the light is 5–10 cm from the top of the petri dish.

Repeat the scoring procedure that you used on Day 4 for the F1 seeds on the F2 seeds to determine expression of the purple stem trait and the dwarf stem height trait. Record the results and percentages in Data Table 2.
Use the forceps to carefully remove the seed plants and place on a paper towel. Organize these into the four categories shown in Data Table 2 and take a photograph of this setup.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: Dispose of the Fast Plants<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> in the trash.
Wash the petri dishes with soap and water and return them to your kit.
Sanitize the work space.

pageData.title: Questions
text: Is the purple stem trait dominant or recessive? Support your conclusion with examples from your data.
Is the dwarf stem height trait dominant or recessive? Support your conclusion with examples from your data.

Based on your data, what are the phenotype and genotype of the Parent 1 (P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub>) plants? What can you deduce to be the phenotype and genotype of the Parent 2 (P<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>) plants?
Based on your data, fill in the Punnett square for the cross of the P<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> and P<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> parental plants.
Based on your data, fill in the Punnett square for the cross of the F<sub class='bodysubscript'>1</sub> plants.

1. Based on the Punnett square above, what is the percentage of offspring that are predicted to have purple stems and dwarf stem height? How did this compare to the results that you obtained in this lab?

1. Based on the Punnett square above, what is the percentage of offspring that are predicted to have non-purple stems and dwarf stem height? How did this compare to the results that you obtained in this lab?

1. Based on the Punnett square above, what is the percentage of offspring that are predicted to have purple stems and normal stem height? How did this compare to the results that you obtained in this lab?

1. Based on the Punnett square above, what is the percentage of offspring that are predicted to have non-purple stems and normal stem height? How did this compare to the results that you obtained in this lab?

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Start by setting up a fluorescent light source. In Activity 1, you will create watering systems for P1 and F1 seeds, then place these seeds in their respective systems. After waiting 3 days, observe the P1 and F1 seedling phenotypes and determine the phenotype percentages. You will then predict the F2 generation phenotypes and proportions. Next, you will create a watering system for F2 seeds and place the seeds in the system. After waiting 3 days, observe the F2 seedling phenotypes and determine the phenotype percentages.

data.title: Allele
data.content: One of two or more versions of a gene

data.title: Dominant
data.content: Describes the trait that is expressed when two different alleles are present

data.title: F generation
data.content: Offspring of the P generation; “F” stands for filial

data.title: Genotype
data.content: The genetic makeup of an individual cell or organism that determines or contributes to the phenotype

data.title: Heterozygous
data.content: Describes a genotype in which two different alleles are inherited

data.title: Homozygous dominant
data.content: Describes a genotype in which both of the alleles that are inherited are for the dominant trait

data.title: Homozygous recessive
data.content: Describes a genotype in which both of the alleles that are inherited are for the recessive trait

data.title: Law of independent assortment
data.content: Mendel's second law which states that all traits are inherited independently of one another

data.title: Law of segregation
data.content: Mendel's first law which states that individuals possess two alleles for each trait

data.title: P generation
data.content: The first two organisms that are crossed; “P” stands for parental

data.title: Phenotype
data.content: The physical expression of a trait

data.title: Punnett square
data.content: A diagram used to show the potential results of genetic crosses

data.title: Recessive
data.content: Describes the trait that not is expressed when two different alleles are present
